lines.text: Do you fall in love with all of your clients?
Only the ones in skirts.

People who write usually don't know the facts, and people who know the facts usually can't write. Authenticity has very little to do with it. If people who read our magazines knew the facts of life, they wouldn't be reading our magazines.

[on Marlowe's submission]
I plan to slash the emotion right out of that story.
Mr. Marlowe, may I speak to you?
Why not? Everybody's been speaking to me.
We get hundreds of authentic cases submitted to us every week.
Why don't you print a few?
They aren't all as emotional as yours.

[to Marlowe]
Perhaps you'd better go home and play with your fingerprint collection.

[learns Marlowe is writing fiction]
What are you trying to do, elevate yourself?
You want the facts, don't you?
When it comes to women, does anybody really want the facts?

[Marlowe's story]
That wasn't for nothing.
No, it was for five hundred bucks, and you got a little piece of my soul, along with my services.

[to Marlowe]
I want to be your girl, that's what I want for Christmas.

[reminiscing on her early career, to Marlowe]
If all the malted milks I served were laid end to end...

[Adrienne pitches Marlowe's story to publisher Derace Kingsby]
And he's a very well-known private detective. That's what makes the stuff so authentic. So full of life and vigor and heart. So full of... what would you say it was full of, Mr. Marlowe?
Short sentences.
How d'you get back from the lake so soon?
Fast dog team.
[Opening lines]

private detective. You know, somebody says, "Follow that guy", so I follow him. Somebody says, "Find that female", so I find her. And what do I get out of it? $10 a day and expenses. And if you think that buys a lot of fancy groceries these days, you're crazy.
[Talking to the audience]
I was tired of being pushed around for nickels and dimes so I decided I'd write about murder. It's safer and besides, they tell me the profits are good.
[Talking to the audience]

You know, some cases of murder start when that door there behind you opens up and a fellow rushes in all covered with sweat and confusion and fills you full of bad dope about the setup. But some cases, like this one, kind of creep up on you on their hands and knees and the first thing you know, you're in it up to your neck.
You don't really want to buy my story, do you, Miss Fromsett?
I was about to offer you $200 for it.

Oh, no, you weren't. Why don't you quit being cute, Miss Fromsett? The real reason you had me up here is because you're looking for a smooth operator who keeps his mouth shut and when you read the story, you said, "Yeah, that's my boy. He's dumb, he's brave and he's cheap." Am I right?
Well, I was about to offer you a commission on a rather delicate and confidential matter...
Then why didn't you pick up the telephone and call me instead of all this Mickey Mouse about a story?

I want you to find Mr. Kingsby's wife without his knowing you're looking for her. She's run off with another man. She's a vicious woman - a liar, a cheat and a thief. She may even end up in the hands of the police. He's had 10 years...
Pardon me if I'm nosey, Miss Fromsett. What makes this any of your business?
I handle all of Mr. Kingsby's affairs. He wishes to divorce her. She must be found before she can be served with the papers.

[Snorts]
Nice job you have here.

[Smiles]
You think I'm pretty cold-blooded about this, don't you?
I'd have used a shorter word.

[In an indignant tone of voice]
I don't like your manner.

I'm not selling it. I'm not selling the story, either, to you. I'm not selling anything. I have an allergy against getting mixed up with tricky females who want to knock off the boss's wife and marry him for themselves.

[Now seriously angry]
People don't talk to me like that, Mr. Marlowe!
Maybe that's what's the matter with you. Somebody should talk to you like that sometime.
I noticed you didn't do much talking while the boss was in the office, did you?
When I made a quick $300 by keeping quiet?
Please don't be so difficult to get along with. I need help.
Like I need four thumbs.
I wonder how it would be to discuss this over a couple of ice cubes. Would you care to try?

[laughs]
Imagine *you* needing ice cubes.
Where does Chris Lavery live?
Bay City.
Address?
676 Altair Street. The edge of the canyon.
And you hope he throws me into it.

[to Chris Lavery]
I like your tan. That's very Christmassy.
Name?
Phillip Marlowe.
You like our jail?
Fine.
When you came out of your blackout, you started slugging so I had to put you to sleep again.
Fine.
Did you sleep nice?
Fine.
Do you remember me at all?
Fine.
Don't you know any other words but "fine"?
The teeth I've got, I'd like to keep.

[to Marlowe]
So you're a story writer too, hmm? The detective business must be on the skids. What are you trying to do, elevate yourself?

[Referring to the story Marlowe wrote]
"If I Should Die Before I Live" - that's not bad.
It might happen to you.
